title: Women with degrees earn three times as much as female non-graduates
text:
0.00 0.00 
There's a '£13,200' graduate premium for women according to a study published today - and £14,500 for men 
Women graduates earn triple the yearly pay over their female counterparts who didn't go to university, an academic report suggests. 
Official figures are also exaggerating the gender pay gap, which is smaller than previously thought, according to researchers at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, a think tank, and Cambridge and Harvard universities. 
Men can double their pay if they went to university, according to their analysis of salary data held by the Student Loans Company and HM Revenue & Customs. 
While a female non-graduate in her early thirties takes home £6,300 median pay, women graduates earn £19,500. For men, graduates earn £25,200 in median income but non-graduates £10,700. 
• Ten best student current accounts: £160 bribe versus £240 pitfall 
The researchers used anonymous tax data and student loan records for the more than 260,000 graduates who studied between 1998 and 2011, looking at their earnings for the year 2011-2012. 
The study puts the gender pay gap for graduates in the 10 years after leaving university at around 23pc, whereas the Labour Force Survey , the nation's largest household survey carried out by official statisticians, suggests it is closer to 33pc. 
The ONS sample is made up of approximately 40,000 households, from around 100,000 individuals who submit responses every three months. 
In the 10 years after graduation, the top-earning 10pc of male graduates take home £55,000 a year, while the highest-paid 10pc of women earn more than £43,000, according to the research published today. 
The top-earning 1pc of male graduates earn £148,000 in the ten years after graduation; among women this is just £89,000. 
• "I paid off my student loan but the deductions won't stop" 
Graduates tend to also be more "recession proof" than non-graduates, the research found. 
In the four years after 2007, male graduates saw their earnings drop 14pc while non-graduate men's income fell 30pc. For women, graduate income fell 20pc and non-graduate by 40pc. 
"The 'graduate premium' we identified was maintained through the recent recession, although all groups saw significant falls in their earnings during this period," the authors said. 
"The value of a degree is therefore particularly true for women," said Jack Britton, a research economist at the IFS. "A degree provides protection from low income and shields graduates from some of the negative impact of the recent recession." 
• Martin Lewis: time to stop calling student loans a loan 
Anna Vignoles of Cambridge University said: "This study illustrates the power of using 'big data' to better understand the graduate labour market. 
"It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) shows that previously we have underestimated the earnings of top graduates."
